text: Hey, everyone?

This is our first time actually meeting.

But I'll let you guys tell them a little bit

So, we started our channel a few years ago.

And basically, we travel around Canada in

lifestyles.
Like living in tiny houses and boats.

Ah, living zero-waste and being minimalist

And while we do that, we are also living in

So, it's a lot of fun.

We meet a lot of really interesting people

They live in a van.

Let's just start with, how long have you been
doing this?
And why did you get into van life?

Well, we've been doing it for about three
years now spending almost half a year living
in a camper van.

And for us it's, it's really practical because
we use the camper van to travel around, meet
different people, film videos.

So, it allows us to move around and stay in
the van instead of staying in hotels and spending
a ton of money.
And yeah, we like it.
It's got its challenges but it's pretty good.
How many vans have you lived in?
Um, we had one before this.
It was a Ford e-150.

It was just like a low top kind of plumbers
van.
And that was really comfy for a few summers.

And then, after a while, we realized that
we were spending a lot of time sitting down
editing videos.
Yeah.

And, and if the weather was bad we couldn't
go outside to cook.

So we decided to invest in this van and we're
kind of 3/4 of the way done building it.
And now Mat can stand up in here.

Yeah.      
 Yeah, you are tall.
So we can stand up.
We can cook. We are going to have a toilet.
It's going to be like really comfy.
A fridge, everything.
Yeah.
So, we've upgraded a little bit.

But we waited three years first to make sure
we were into it before spending more money.
And that's what we usually recommend for people.
Is like try it first.

Even if you sleep in your own car for a night
or rent a vehicle for a week or something
like that.
Yeah.
Because it is different.
It's odd to just sleep in a car.
You know what I mean?
Right.
It's not something that most people do.

So, online it might seem different than it
is in real life.
Yeah.
So, yeah.
Try before you buy.
Yeah. The first van we bought was $4,000.
Pretty cheap.
And we did like some very basic modifications.

So, we really didn't spend much money on the

And we really tried it out for a few years
to really make sure that we wanted to keep

Right.
And what, what is it that made you keep going?

I am sure there is many things, but like what,
what's a couple things that comes to mind?
Living in a van is often really hard.
Really challenging.
Everything is amplified.
If it's hot, it's hotter in the van.
If it's cold, it's colder.
Yeah.
And if it's raining it's really challenging.

But the good, the good stuff is really, really
awesome.
We get to see some incredible places.
We've met tons of amazing people.

And on top of that, for us it's, kind of become
a necessity.

We need to keep moving around to do what we're
doing.

So, it's our office and our home on wheels,
so.

We also, we knew we wanted to travel and we
want to explore a lot of different places.

But we didn't want to have a home base because
when we first started we couldn't afford to

have a home base and be traveling at the same
time.

So, let's say we went on a trip for a few
months and we came back, we wanted to have
our own space.

And then our families don't all live in the
same places so we wanted to be able to visit
them and travel around.

And so, having a mobile home of some kind
made the most sense.
Yeah.
Yeah.
You can like do all that.
Exactly.
And save money.
Yeah.

And you can go visit and spend time with people
but then go back into your own space and not
like, you know, overstay your welcome.
Right.
Yeah.
Right.
Yeah.
Which we tend to do something still but.

[laughter] So, ah, we've been living the van

Pretty much half the year, ah, we'll be staying

Awesome.
Yeah.

Like you are.
Yeah.
It's an exchange.
It's an exchange.
It's a kind of an exchange.

If there's problems with the house you take

Pets too.
Pets.

So, you manage the house and take care of

Just like the monthly budget.

Uh-huh.

um.
Cheap.
That is cheap in Canada.
It's pretty good.
Yeah.

It was the most we had ever spent, but it

We could just like walk to the grocery store

So, 1, 000 bucks a month.

And then if we compare that to living in the

If we stay in a campground once a week, just
to get like a good night's sleep shower, refill
the water, that's probably another 200.

Repairs, maybe 100 or 200 a month if you spread
it out.
That's where most of the money goes.
Repairs.
Repairs.

Even if this van is a 2015, we bought it used

it.
There is always something.

There is always something that breaks in a

And usually, if you've gotten a cheaper van,

So, it's just the reality.

I mean, it's some people don't believe us

It's your home.

People spend probably so much more in repairing

Yeah.
Because there's more to break.

Yeah.
Right?
Yeah.

Like already, this is our second day in the

So, that's probably going to be a few hundred
bucks.
You know, little things like that.

And then for gas, it obviously depends on

Where we are.

Gas is cheaper in the U.S. from what we've

Right?
Totally.
Repairs, insurance and all that.

So, it can be cheap but then, it's not as

Yeah.

But people who have houses or apartments,

Except, yours is also your home.
Yap.

Yes.

And we've never had a problem.

No. [laughter] People's driveway.
Can we use your shower?
Anyone's driveway.

Too much.
Too much Walmart.
Too many Walmarts.

Doing a ton of driving in a day.

And it's because we work too.
We're not just on vacation, you know.

Some people who want to live in a van, it's

Like for a summer, they just want to go drive

And so we know that the Walmarts that allow

Right.

Um, but anywhere we sleep, anywhere we spend

We don't make any noise.
We don't like dump anything.
We are really, really respectful.

We try to think, if everyone did what we did,

And so we tried to to act in a way that, yeah,
that it wouldn't ruin it for everyone else.
Be responsible van lifer.
Mm-hmm.
That's a tip to take away.

Sort of forces you to meet new people too.
You don't stay in your little couple as much.

We know some women who travel in their vans

And yeah it depends on the person.

I can see how maybe I wouldn't enjoy it on

Yeah, it depends if how outgoing you are.

You might be an introvert or something and

Because sometimes even when we're two it's

Yeah.
Like I don't know, we'll be parked somewhere.
You think everything is weird though.

It's raining all.

And then you are like, "Hey.

Heats up in the sun.

They are great.

I love it.
Outdoor shower.

Go swimming.
Nice.

So good.
Um, and I have reusable pants.
Mm-hmm.
Which I can just rinse.
And recently, I have got a period proof underwear.
Oh, I have seen those.

Are they great?
They are really great.

But you can leave the diva cup in for longer.
Yeah.
Like 12 hours.
Right.
So it's not like a tampon or a pad.

Manageable.

It's hot.
It's cold.

Yeah, and what you mentioned.

Just finding parking it can be very, very

And it can really test a relationship.

We just kind of get used to like when it's

I think life becomes really simple.

So the downside of like having to manage every

It's just like, where am I going to sleep

You know what I mean?

To things that people used to just like have

And then like you guys mentioned in the video

I am going and I am just not going to pay

Something in the van.
